Clam Man is an adventure game where you are the protagonist (ie, a walking Clam) trying to solve a mystery of sorts. It aims to be a funny game with an outlandish plot and wacky conversations. Generally I think it is well done. The art and music are obviously low budget and it's fine for an indie game.

For the cons, my biggest gripe is the horrendous UI and stability. The game was crashing every 20-30 minutes and keeping my CPU maxed at 100% the entire time. Kind of inexcusable given the very simple game. Even though your character only moves left and right, you still need to click and can't use the arrows. The speech is super lazy appearing above the head of the characters - the game uses a lot of very short sentences (for example, just ellipsis like "...") and sometimes you are just waiting to see what happens when the game is actually waiting on you to see two tiny dots. In an attempt to be witty there are way too many options in the conversations where you need to scroll down repeatedly. Lastly, the game is very short at 1.5-2 hours and as joked in one of the endings, is more a visual novel than an adventure game given how there is only 1 path to do things.

If the game was stable it would be a borderline positive recommendation but as it stands, too frustrating to play - good thing it was short so I didn't need to suffer too long! 3/10

Lastly for achievement hunters, it just takes one playthrough to get everything but you need to follow the Steam Guide as some of the trophies are missable and you cannot use chapter select so you would need to replay the game. Sometimes following a guide 'ruins' an adventure game, but in this case there was not much to explore anyway so no problems there.

A short and sweet point-and-click adventure, "Clam Man" takes 4 - 4.5 hours to complete in one sitting. After those four hours, you may find yourself driving to the local Red Lobster for more high-octane mollusk action. The charming hand-drawn aesthetic of the game's underwater setting, Snacky Bay, and its fishy inhabitants never loses its appeal. The writing will keep you grinning and chuckling during the entire play-through, and it feels wholly well paced. The story is easy to follow, but it will keep you glued to the screen to see what happens next in Clam Man's epic journey. Every character has a distinct personality, and one may want to explore every dialogue option just to get a sliver of that witty script. There are some jokes disguised as references (particularly during the final scenes) that may not land if you are unaware of them, but they will not take away from the total enjoyment that "Clam Man" offers.

The small team behind this game believed in their product, and that is evident throughout the game. The many small details and interactions that you will discover from exploring the nooks and crannies of Snacky Bay will turn that frown upside-down. This game is a breath of fresh air, and I highly recommend that you inhale deeply.

[h1]Big trouble in little Bivalvia [/h1]

Clam Man is a point & click adventure game from Team Clam. You play as Clam Man, a naïve bivalve who gets the rug pulled out from under him and is forced into an investigation that goes all the way to the top! It’s hard to be anymore specific without spoiling the game, but as the store page says it’s a pretty absurd narrative. Lots of fun though.

[h1]Positives: [/h1]
[*]The art style is a pretty casual cartoon-y style, I really like it and I think it fits the game well. It reminded me of the first Nelly Cootalot game, which is the game that got me into point & clicks. 

[*]Clam Man’s main draw is the humor, and they sure did deliver. I don’t think I’ve laughed out loud at a game more than I have with Clam Man. The jokes are consistently good over the course of the game, and I don’t think you need a specific sense of humor to enjoy them. There’s also a lot of really well done meta jokes that I thoroughly enjoyed. 

[*]The plot itself is fairly compelling. Despite being pretty wacky, it’s fairly straightforward, but I enjoyed watching it unfold. I don’t think it’s super duper original, but it’s entertaining and well-executed.

[*]Most of your time with the game is spent reading the dialog, I found it to be compelling stuff for the most part. The characters are well varied, and they did a good job of making them have distinct personalities. 

[*]Music is used to great effect to really set the scene at certain points throughout the game. [/list]

[h1]Neutral: [/h1]
[list][*]Other than a couple of puzzles to solve, this is a pretty hands-off experience. Personally, I enjoy a story-heavy/gameplay-light game every once in a while, but some people may not be too keen on the lack of interaction. [/list]

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
[list][*]While I did enjoy the plot, I did kind of feel like it lacked some depth. I would have liked to know a little bit more about the relationships between some of the characters and the game did kind of feel like it was over just as it had begun. 

[*]There’s no scene/chapter select once you finish the game, so if you miss out on any of the achievements you have to replay the whole thing to get them. [/list]

[h1]Verdict: [/h1]

Clam Man is a hilarious little game with compelling dialog and a wacky plot. For a game set underwater, it does lack a little depth, but this is an easy recommendation for comedic adventure game fans.

I really wanted to like Clam Man, and I did, but I had the thought "the sequel is going to be amazing" more often than "THIS game is amazing."

You play as a clam/human hybrid who is trying to get to the bottom of a conspiracy involving a mayonnaise company. The story is wacky but not overly so, and the dialogue is very, very funny. The game has some 4th wall breaking humour, as well as sharp comedy in the interactions between characters. Your character isn't a bumbling fool, nor a genius, but manages a nice middle-ground which few adventure games achieve. The game is genuinely hilarious. I can't think of a single joke which failed to land, and it doesn't rely on cheap gags, which is a rarity in comedy games.

The graphics are pleasant and the soundtrack works well, but they are both clearly a low-budget affair. The animation of the mobsters in particular reminded me of old flash games, and the not infrequent graphical bugs compound this. There is no voice acting, instead getting a quiet bobbling sound (which doesn't vary for different characters?) but some well-placed sound effects do work well.

The biggest problem I have with clam man is the lack of gameplay. You have an inventory, which only becomes important about half way through the game, and which only holds about 6 items total through the entirety of the game. There's only really 2 proper puzzles to speak of. One is a simple inventory puzzle and the other is a logic-style minipuzzle. This second puzzle is weirdly very difficult, so feels a bit out of place. In addition to the puzzles, the dialogue trees generally speaking need to be exhausted, as sometimes options will result in the game progressing in a way you couldn't have predicted. Worse still, they need to be exhausted in order - a couple of times I chose options out of order and the resulting conversation made less sense.

As a result, this game can feel too often like a slideshow. You don't have to think, you just click through everything in order and enjoy the (admittedly very entertaining) results. There's a joke in the game about Clam Man 2, and I just really hope that becomes a reality, and the team makes a game with some nice puzzles and traditional adventure gaming woven in. Clam Man is one of very few games I laughed out loud at, so they clearly are very talented and have a great base to work on here.

[i]Clam Man[/i] is probably the closest we are ever going to get to a new Humongous Entertainment game. It's basically a less kid-friendly [i]Spy Fox[/i]. It's got the aesthetic down, the music is fantastic and appropriately jazzy-y and noir-ish, and it never takes itself too seriously.

The only real downside (and it isn't much of one) for me, personally, is that I felt like there were a few instances where the humor fell flat. Referencing popular internet videos and "internet dialogue" just kind of dates the game, and seems like a cheap attempt at humor. I also thought a certain character could have been more effective if he were an original idea as opposed to an obvious parody of a popular cartoon.

Other than that, though, I have no qualms. The game only has one really big puzzle; and one playthrough will only be a few hours at the most (it's about as long as a [i]HE[/i] game, actually), but succinct games are a-okay in my book.

Pros
-------------------------------------------------
-The game is just hilarious.  Great dialogue/monologues and 4th wall breaking humor. 
-A true P&C style adventure story: funny, absurdist, and unique
-Graphical style gives a look like it was painted by hand.  
-Great original soundtrack, funny songs ("...ROPE!....KNOTS!...")
-Made with the Unity engine.  No weird setup issues like AGS can sometimes have.
-Subtle pop culture references (hitchhikers guide to the galaxy, stranger things, star wars)


Meh.
-------------------------------------------------
-No voices.  All characters make a noise like the teacher from the snoopy cartoons.
-Some minor bugs (Some issues with music volume conflicting with the speaking noise/speaking noise not playing at all, couldn't access game menu in front of apartment)
-A few cases where the music looping had an abrupt replay transition.
-Dialogue/Monologue intensive game play.  Not as bad as Randal's Monday, but between this and a lack of inventory usage( more on this later) it makes it feel more like a visual novel/dialogue-choices-matter game.


Cons
-------------------------------------------------
-A called this a true P&C story, however it is not true P&C style game play.  What I mean by this namely is a real lack of inventory usage or interactions.  I consider this its big drawback as a P&C aficionado and would love to have seen more inventory interaction puzzles.
-At $10 asking price for approx. 2 hrs game play it is kind of pricey for a P&C game.
-No save slots.
-No ability to pause game or dialogue


To recap I consider this game to have a very high quality story, dialogue, background music/sound effects, and overall game stability.  If your still reading this and are a P&C aficionado like myself, stop and just buy it already!

Clam Man is a short, highly amusing point and click adventure game, about a clam man named Clam Man, and his quest for JUSTICE.

The game is packed to the brim with fun characters, lots of humor, and fish puns.
I finished it in ~3 hours, and enjoyed my time playing it.

To start with a couple of potential turn-offs, Clam Man is short and, as far as point-and-click adventures go, doesn't have too many puzzles. In this case, by "too many" I mean four. Because the game has three. Still, it's three puzzles more than some other modern games have.

However, despite my overall predilection for games with at least four puzzles, I wasn't disappointed at all! Most importantly, the game has extraordinarily good writing. The dialogues are fresh, original and impressive. Most characters are colorful and very likeable. And a bit insane. But that's good, right?

The humor is another great point in favor of this game. Fans of Monty Python will feel right at home in the weird fish world and its story (especially somewhere around the middle of the game).

To sum it all up, recommended to everyone who can read and laugh. Because you will.

A short but sweet point and click adventure. Pretty much every screen is filled to the brim with some sort of interactable to use as a vehicle for another joke or reference, but it never feels overbearing. The art was one of the main initial draws for me and it delivered throughout, evoking memories of the point and click games of my childhood while retaining it's own style.

You'll know if you'll enjoy the game and it's writing if you enjoy the way the description is written. While it's mostly jokes, there's a tangible fun story to go through as simple as it may be. It knows what it is and plays around with a lot of referential and 4th wall humor to help guide it, but doesn't rely on it for laughs. There's quite a few times I had to catch my breath before continuing after a joke.

The puzzles are usually only a few steps removed from simple intuitive solutions, so they're not brainbusters by any means but there's still a few satisfying solutions to be found. They are mostly used as a vehicle for another joke, whether it's meta or not, which usually pay off in a fun way.

Overall it feels like a chapter from any one of the famous point and clicks was taken out and morphed into it's own game - you're not going to get a sweeping epic story but you'll have a fun time in a weird location with some wacky characters and probably get at least a few laughs out of your time. If you want a bite size point and click short story, you've come to the right clam.

Clam Man has a lot of charm and I enjoyed my playthrough quite a bit. I laughed several times through the adventure, and as someone with the personality of a robot, that's kind of hard to achieve. Since the game was obviously made from a small team, they needed to put their effort where it mattered, which in this case is the writing, and I think they made the right call. Since 90% of this game is basically setup of the scene followed by a string of jokes, it's important that at least some of them land, and I'd say that most do (it's really hard to critique comedy, so maybe I'm super wrong). in any case, none of the jokes outstay their welcome. There might have been a bit too many references for me, since those don't tend to age that well, but at least they were references to things I enjoy.

I'm not sure if this is just me missing the point entirely, or if there's merit to my criticism, but I kind of wish there would have been more to the actual writing of the plot and characters. I suspect that when you write something that has to be simplified in order to make the jokes more pronounced, character depth might need to suffer for it, but I always hope that isn't the case. That said, Clam Man and His Amazing Friends are likable, and he at least has a clear goal, and sometimes that's all you need to set the stage.

There's not a lot of puzzles, and the ones that are there don't really require any logic that makes you feel clever or inventive. It almost feels like they exist only because that's the genre. It is nice, however, that they occasionally use the genre to play with your expectations.

In the end I had a lot of fun. While the characters weren't exactly deep, all of them were instantly charming and consistently made me smile. It's also nice to play a nice little indie game made by actual human beings who want you to have a good time. I recommend it! If you miss the dense, sometimes wacky humor of Monkey Island or Sam & Max, or don't even know what that's like, you should give this a try!
